DATA_2020_CSC = READ_CSC_CCL_2020.variables["coscbbgl"][0,:,:]
DATA_2021_CSC = READ_CSC_CCL_2021.variables["coscbbgl"][0,:,:]

DATA_2020_CCL = READ_CSC_CCL_2020.variables["colsbbgl"][0,:,:]
DATA_2021_CCL = READ_CSC_CCL_2021.variables["colsbbgl"][0,:,:]

CSC_CCL_LON = READ_CSC_CCL_2020.variables["longitude"][:] 
CSC_CCL_LAT = READ_CSC_CCL_2020.variables["latitude"][:]
source.d1ae0aca:
figure = plt.figure(figsize=(12,7))

axis_func = plt.axes(projection=ccrs.SouthPolarStereo())
axis_func.set_global()

axis_func.coastlines(resolution="110m",linewidth=2)
axis_func.gridlines(linestyle='--',color='black',linewidth=1)

axis_func.set_extent([-180, 180, -90, -60], ccrs.PlateCarree())

plt.contourf(CSC_CCL_LON, CSC_CCL_LAT, DATA_2020_CCL, transform=ccrs.PlateCarree(),cmap="hot")

color_bar_func = plt.colorbar(ax=axis_func, orientation="vertical", pad=0.05, aspect=16, shrink=0.8, extend="max")
color_bar_func.ax.tick_params(labelsize=8)

plt.title(READ_CSC_CCL_2020.variables["coscbbgl"].long_name + "2020")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

figure = plt.figure(figsize=(12,7))

axis_func = plt.axes(projection=ccrs.SouthPolarStereo())
axis_func.set_global()

axis_func.coastlines(resolution="110m",linewidth=2)
axis_func.gridlines(linestyle='--',color='black',linewidth=1)

axis_func.set_extent([-180, 180, -90, -60], ccrs.PlateCarree())

plt.contourf(CSC_CCL_LON, CSC_CCL_LAT, DATA_2021_CCL, transform=ccrs.PlateCarree(),cmap="hot")

color_bar_func = plt.colorbar(ax=axis_func, orientation="vertical", pad=0.05, aspect=16, shrink=0.8, extend="max")
color_bar_func.ax.tick_params(labelsize=8)

plt.title(READ_CSC_CCL_2020.variables["coscbbgl"].long_name + "2021")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

source.a49ae93e:
# HISTORY

* Sensible heat flux and latent heat flux represent the heat transfer between the land surface and the atmosphere due to temperature differences and water vapor phase transitions, respectively. Land surface heat fluxes are essential to land–atmosphere interactions in the atmospheric boundary layer. The sensible heat flux is the transfer of heat caused by the difference in temperature between the sea and the air. The variability of land surface heat fluxes may originate from land use land cover changes and natural variations, which could serve as an indicator of land cover change over both the artificial and natural underlying surface. Land surface heat fluxes can directly influence the land surface temperature, which is an important driver of local warming. Furthermore, variations in land surface heat fluxes will also have an impact on the atmospheric circulation and climate change, which are of great significance to the study of energy exchange in land–atmosphere interactions.

* The concentration of carbon monoxide in air can be represented using various concentration units. Air monitoring data for carbon monoxide are usually expressed or reported as either parts per million by volume (ppmv) or parts per billion by volume (ppbv). A concentration of 1 ppmv implies that for every million molecules of gas in the measured volume, one of them is a carbon monoxide molecule. however, the quantity of carbon monoxide emitted from automobiles has been declining significantly over the past 4 decades due to the use of emission control devices and catalytic converters. Indoor air levels of carbon monoxide are highly dependent upon the smoking habits, the types of appliances and heating units that are used in the home or building, and whether or not the home or building has an attached garage for automobiles. Annual average outdoor carbon monoxide concentrations are about 0.12 ppmv in the Northern Hemisphere and about 0.04 ppmv in the Southern Hemisphere (EPA 2000). In general, the concentration of carbon monoxide decreases with altitude in the Northern Hemisphere, but this vertical gradient may be reversed in the Southern Hemisphere due to the transport of carbon monoxide from the Northern to the Southern Hemisphere.
